section.title: Web Site Scripting with PHP
section.para: Project members can build sophisticated project Web sites by using the PHP language. PHP, an Open Source equivalent to Microsoft ASP, is becoming extremely popular as a server-side scripting language for the Web. PHP is easy to learn, optimized for the Web and interact nicely with SQL databases.

If you decide to embed PHP scripts in your Project Web pages, first make sure to use the ".php" extensions for all the files with PHP code in it. For pure HTML pages use the "htm" or "html" extensions as usual.

CodeX offers a system wide include file called "pre_vhosts.php" that you should include at the very top of all your PHP pages if you want to be given access to the current user, session and group (project) information. This include file create various variables functions and objects that can be helpful in your PHP scripts:

section.title: Web Site Publishing
section.para: You can use various methods to publish your Web pages on your CodeX Web site:

listitem.para: Remote editing with HTML capable editors like Netscape or Mozilla Composer, Microsoft FrontPage or Emacs with transparent ftp access
Local editing on your machine and transfer of the files either via ftp or, even better, via scp
Small changes to web pages can be made from the shell account on CodeX, using emacs or vi, but substantial editing is discouraged.

section.title: Netscape Composer 4.x
section.para: You can use Netscape Composer 4.x to edit remote HTML pages. To do this browse your project Web Page, then use the File->Edit Page menu item, edit your HTML document and finally press on the Publish icon on the upper menu bar.
In the dialog box specify the following parameters:

listitem.para: Upload Files to this location:
Login and Password: type your CodeX login and password. Click on the save password checkbox to avoid retyping the password for each Save operation.

section.title: Netscape Composer 6.x
section.para: With Netscape version 6 (or Mozilla 1.0) it is no longer possible to publish a page without first storing a local copy. In order to use the Netscape 6 publishing mechanism first create your Web site structure and pages on your desktop machine, work with this local copy and then publish the pages via FTP as needed.

As an alternative Windows users can also map a network drive pointing directly to the Projects directory on CodeX (see ) and work with the HTML files as if they were located on the local machine. In this case no publishing is required.

section.title: Microsoft FrontPage
section.para: You can't use the Publish feature of FrontPage because the CodeX server doesn't support the FrontPage Web extensions. In addition, publishing through FTP won't work either because FrontPage does not allow you to fully specify the path to the remote of your project Web server. A work around consist in mounting the Windows network drive at \\codex\projects (see ) and work directly on your remote Web server directories.

section.title: Macromedia Dreamweaver
section.para: You can use DreamWeaver to design and create your project web site. As opposed to FrontPage, DreamWeaver fully support remote publication via FTP. To create a new site go to the Site -> New Site menu. In the local information, choose your site name and local root folder. For the remote information, choose FTP access and specify projectname.&SYS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN; as host and /home/groups/projectname/htdocs as the host directory. The login is your CodeX login.

section.title: Referencing the CodeX Site
section.para: The CodeX Team is asking that all project Web sites hosted on CodeX display the CodeX logo on their front page. And ideally it would be great if you also cross-reference our site on other pages that are located on other servers. The rationale behind this request is twofold:

listitem.para: First, by referencing the CodeX site on your Web page you will allow your visitors to learn about the existence of the CodeX site, give them a chance to visit it and also let them learn about other projects hosted on CodeX. By doing so you will augment the opportunity for re-use.

The second reason is that using the CodeX logo in your Web site will automatically increase the Web access counter that CodeX is maintaining for you. The number of accesses to your site can be viewed by visiting your Project Summary page and click on the "Statistics" link below the project description (see ). This will also help us to identify projects that may require additional hosting resources due to large amounts of activity.
